basics.name: Julie R. Pivin-Bachler
basics.summary: Currently completing a PhD in Cybernetics (expected to end in November 2026), I am a curious and motivated researcher focused on non-standard cases in computing. My research addresses accessibility for users with impairments, alongside issues of data imbalance and model generalizability. I also work a lot with biosignals for affect recognition. I am driven to conduct research that has tangible social impact to help others.

latest publications.name: Automatic Ability-Based Design (AutoABD): A Novel Framework for Accessible Technology Evaluated on Visual Abilities
latest publications.summary: Introduction of autoABD, a framework that automatically adapts to its users' abilities. autoABD's feasibility is demonstrated on users with and without vision impairment, where users with a vision impairment are correctly identified and equivalent accessibility is achieved.

latest publications.name: SIMBA: A robust and generalizable measure of data imbalance
latest publications.summary: This paper critically reviews all existing imbalance measures and introduces the Status of IMBAlance (SIMBA), a robust and generalizable imbalance measure. Indeed, SIMBA can be used on datasets with any number of classes, features, and samples, and accurately reflects classification difficulty stemming from imbalanced data.
